title: Coffee Shop Wait Times & 5-Number Summary
original_question: A student recorded waiting times (in minutes) for 15 customers: 2.5, 3.1, 4.0, 1.2, 5.5, 3.8, 4.2, 8.0, 2.9, 3.3, 4.1, 3.5, 3.0, 4.5, 2.8. The manager claims 'Most customers get coffee in under 4 minutes.' Provide the 5-number summary and evaluate the claim.

segments.explanation: Data must be sorted ascending to find quartiles and median.

segments.text: The manager claims 'Most customers get coffee in under 4 minutes.'
segments.explanation: If the median is below 4, the claim is statistically 'mostly' true.

traps.title: Sorting Priority
traps.description: Calculating the median from the raw unsorted list is the most common error in EDA.

solution.content: The median is 3.5, meaning 50% of customers wait 3.5 mins or less. 10/15 (67%) wait 4 mins or less. The claim is accurate.

title: Gasoline Octane Outlier Detection
original_question: An inspection of 20 gas samples yielded octane ratings: 87.1, 87.5, 88.0, 89.2, 90.1, 87.8, 88.5, 91.0, 87.2, 88.8, 89.5, 90.0, 88.2, 87.9, 88.4, 89.1, 90.5, 87.3, 88.7, 990.4. Use the 1.5*IQR rule to check if 990.4 is an outlier. If removed, what is the new Upper Whisker?

segments.explanation: A rating of 990.4 is physically impossible for octane (usually 85-105).

traps.title: Whisker vs. Fence
traps.description: The upper whisker is the largest data point *below* the fence, not the fence value itself.

solution.content: $Upper Fence = 89.75 + (1.5 \cdot 1.9) = 92.6$. Since $990.4 > 92.6$, it is an outlier.
Excluding 990.4, the largest remaining value in the dataset is 91.0. The Upper Whisker = 91.0.
